wikipedia_page.main: John Armstrong (20 January 1857 – 27 April 1941) was a Scottish architect and civil engineer operating in Scotland in the late 19th century. He was a Quaker, and appears to have done much work for the Society of Friends.

response: *John Armstrong Jr. (1758–1843), soldier and U.S. Secretary of War
*John Armstrong Sr. (1717–1795), American general and Continental Congressman
*John Armstrong (Carolina) (1735–1784), American soldier and land registrar
*John Armstrong (of Carrick) (1909–1984), farmer and musician from Northumberland
*John Armstrong, New Zealand Army, made calculations for the Te Rata Bridge

Carrubbers Close Mission was founded in 1858 and its 'workers' originally met in a former Atheist Meeting House in Carrubbers Close. The Rev. James Gall (1808–1895) was the founder of the  Mission. In 1883 the American evangelist Dwight L. Moody came to Edinburgh. He was accompanied by Ira D. Sankey who sang his self-composed songs while Moody preached. During their visit, they managed to raise £10,000 to pay for a permanent home for the mission and later that year, the foundation stone was laid. The building was designed by the Edinburgh architect, John Armstrong.Dictionary of Scottish Architects: John Armstrong
